Early reports of ebolavirus studies in HIS mice were based on work in NOD/SCID Il2rɣ c
−/− mice engrafted with human PBL (NSG-huPBL) using both mouse-adapted and wild-type EBOV [ 36]. Similar to infection in non-HIS mice, wild-type EBOV infection did not result in lethal disease in NSG-huPBL. Later, studies were performed using more advanced HIS models [ 56, 57]. The human cell-engrafted NOD.Cg- Prkdc scid Il2rg tm1Wjl Tg (HLA-A2.1) 1Enge/Sz mice (hu-NSG-A2) that express human HLA-A2 provided the first platform for a lethal EBOV mouse model without the need of prior virus adaption to the host [ 38]. Lethal disease is observed in hu-NSG-A2 following intraperitoneal [ 58] or intranasal inoculation with the prototypic EBOV Mayinga strain [ 37].
